content.description: Stick clip the first bolt, hidden crimpers and huecos scattered about. A few different variations on this one.
content.protection: 2 bolts, chain anchors
content.location: Second route you come to from the access trail

content.description: Climb the system of wavy bulges balancing your way to the top. The grade is much harder if you stick to the face rather than stem the aretes behind you. After the halfway point, the grade again depends on how much you roam side to side, sticking to the bolt line is again much bolder and harder.
content.protection: 4 bolts to ring anchors
content.location: In a gap between two blunt aretes towards the far left side of the wall around the corner.

climbs.name: Take That Stopper and Shove It

content.description: Nice finger locks to large holds above. Fairly consistent climbing that requires some figuring out.
content.protection: 3 bolts to chain anchors (now has separate anchor to the right of the old shared anchor). See beta photo for Butcher Shop.
content.location: Behind the large boulder in the middle of Minor Wall

content.description: A crimpy and moderately powerful crux down low to get established on the face. Getting through the bulge is easier but still fun.
content.protection: 3 bolts to chain anchor above bulge with lowering biners
content.location: On the arete to the right of the large boulder at the base as you look at the wall.

content.description: This hidden gem is the test piece route for Minor Wall with a subtle crux sequence that may take several attempts to figure out (get creative). Prior to figuring out the crux, I would have rated this route at one star or less, but after unlocking the right beta it became one of my favorites at Minor Wall. Like most of Minor Wall, there are very few climbs at Socorro as unique as this one.
content.protection:
One can place a small stopper or a #1 (blue) Metolius Master Cam in the crack on the left side of the nugget. There is also a good spot for a #3 (orange) Master Cam just above the top of the nugget. Above that there is a bolt which protects the crux. After the crux there is a rusty piton, half dislodged and bent, but still seemingly solid. The piton can be backed up with a #4 (red) Master Cam just above or a stopper behind the large flake at the top. Be careful on the last holds below the flake at the top, some of that rock is pretty loose and would come off in big chunks, 

  There are two old SMC hangers on star drive "bolts" just over the lip and right of the crack. From this ledge one can easily scramble out via a short gully or climb the next face to a two bolt anchor and clean the route from there (see the beta photo on Hangover Crack). 

  I plan to go back and replace the fixed hardware in the near future so I'll update this info when I do.
content.location: Sorry Angel and Hangover Crack are towards the far climber's left end of Minor Wall, just around the corner from the big jog in the cliff line and the giant boulder. Look for the thin seam with a two foot nugget wedged in the bottom. This is Sorry Angel.

content.description: Great practice route for trad leading
content.protection: All natural pro, ring anchors
content.location: The low angle crack in the middle of Minor Wall (in the 90deg corner)

content.description: Great technique climb for working lie backs, finger locks and stemming. Full nutritional value climbing and one of the better routes at Minor Wall.
content.protection: 4 bolts to rap chain anchors. (Original trad line uses all natural pro bottom to top)
content.location: Immediately left of the low angle crack in the middle of Minor Wall (Son of Sam)

content.description: Low angle kiddo climb. There are a number variations to try on the arete face, or climb the crack system to the right.
content.protection: Mainly a TR route for kids, but potential for gear in the crack to the right. Bolts were added to make setting the top rope easier and for teaching lead climbing.
content.location: Furthest left route as you face Minor Wall

content.description: Bouldery start, but if you find the right holds, they're positive and juggy. The finish is low angle and at one time was a slab walk off. Anchors have since been added.
content.protection: 4 bolts to ring anchors
content.location: On the arete just around the corner from the first face you come to from the access trail. At the south end of the large boulder.

content.description: Super unique movement, unlike anything else in Socorro. There are holds hiding here and there that make this easier than it looks, but still engaging and difficult to onsight. If this route were 30' taller, it would be a classic.
content.protection: 3 bolts to chain anchors
content.location: Find the dihedral low angle crack in the middle of Minor Wall (Son of Sam). Facing the crack, this climb is on the far left of the left wall of the dihedral. It climbs the right side of the arete on the left side of this wall.

content.description: Powerful moves to start, then a nice rest at the horizontal seam. The crux is getting through the pockets near the fourth bolt. Lots of pockets to choose from and several finger orientation variations in each pocket. Be warned, some of the pockets are pretty sharp!
content.protection: 4 bolts to chain anchors with lowering biners
content.location: Squeezed in on the left side of the southern most wall

content.description: The middle line of the Socorro Louie routes. Bouldery moves to the first and only bolt, then continue on straight up between the two seams (left SL and SL Bags another) to either set of chains. Place pro to either side, but climb directly up the middle. Slightly on the contrived side as routes go.
content.protection: 1 silver SMC hanger bolt + natural pro
content.location: On the taller wall to the left of Son of Sam (which is the low angle crack in the middle of Minor Wall). This line climbs between the two bolted Socorro Louie lines.

content.description:
Fun climbing with an alternating crimps, jug, crimps, jug sequence. Great clipping stances holding the intermittent large holes. It's easier than it looks from afar and one of the better lines at this crag. 

  Take caution clipping the first bolt if you don's stick clip it. The corner block that serves as the clipping hold is fractured around the base and could come off.
content.protection: Three bolts to chain anchors with lowering biners. (Orginal trad version: place a large cam in the lower hueco, then natural pro, plus the last bolt near the chains)
content.location: Immediately right of Minor Aretion on the same face, and to the left of the low angle crack (Son of Sam) in the middle of Minor Wall.

climbs.name: Harley Davidson Son of a Gun

content.description: Stick clip the first bolt on this one...Starts with a cool flag move, hanging by one arm from the side pull in the large hueco near the bottom. Then its slightly overhanging crimping up the the third and final bolt. Get a good shake here. From the last bolt to the anchors it's a matter of semi-positive crimps and finding good holds to clip the anchors.
content.protection: 3 bolts (painted red), chain anchors
content.location: Towards the left side of the first wall that you come to from the approach trail

content.description: Climb the left leaning crack with lots of interesting moves (jams, gastons, finger locks, jugs) and goodies hiding deep in the back of the crack. If this route were 20' taller it would be classic. This route can easily be top roped by rappeling from the two bolt anchor at the top of the wall (see beta photo) or scrambling down to the chain anchor directly above the route.
content.protection: Takes nuts and small to medium cams (up to 1 BD Camelot). Protects surprisingly well given the flaring cracks. A new anchor was added with chains just over the top of the ledge to the right (so it lines up with the general line of the climbing). When you reach the last 3 feet of the crack, go straight up to reach this anchor rather than follow the crack off to the left.
content.location: On the right side of the large face around the corner from Minor Aretion

content.description: Obvious high ball on the Handlebar Willy wall.  Climb through good pockets up to a top out right of the roof that may give you pause.
content.protection: Crash pad(s)
content.location: Handlebar Willy wall.  Outcrop uphill from the road on your left if you are traveling from the Northern to Southern area.  Look for a pull out past an old gate crossing.  Many other problems exist in this area.

content.description: The route starts with a couple shallow pockets leading to larger pockets near the first bolt. Then transition left to some interesting side pulls and finger locks. Quite short, but sustained and unique climbing.
content.protection: 2 bolts, chain anchor
content.location: Immediately right of the lichen streak

content.description: Less difficult start using the holds on Hangover Crack to get going, or try the much harder (and yet-to-be-done) direct start. Three separate engaging cruxes make this route a lot of fun and unique.
content.protection: Three bolts to a two bolt anchor with chains and rings.
content.location: Starts just right of the Hangover Crack below a large, thin block stuck to the arete.

content.description:
Very short climb with some crummy rock quality to start. Used to share an anchor with Take that Stopper and Shove It, but now has it's own anchor to the left. 

  After getting established above the horizontal flake, there are some sloper sidepulls high and left. Also small sidepull options to the right. The crux is finding good feet to move from bolts 2 to 3.
content.protection: 3 bolts, hangers with quicklinks anchors and lowering biners (now a separate anchor to the left, rather than the old shared anchor with take that stopper and shove it)
content.location: The right wall in the shady corner in the middle of Minor Wall, in front of the large boulder.

content.description: Similar climbing to Whispering Huecos. Hidden pockets here and there. Difficult to onsight because it's not immediately apparent which pockets are good. The crux is getting over the upper bulge.
content.protection: 3 bolts, chain anchors on pinnacle with lowering biners
content.location: First line you come to from the access trail

content.description:
All but forgotten, this quiet crag has some interesting mixed, trad, and sport climbing. The routes are short. The base of the routes is a nice spot for kids or dogs to run around. Shade varies by season and time of day. The wall faces a number of directions, mostly south and west. One can climb here all year round. 

  The style of climbing is fun, wacky, sequency, and engaging. Some of the routes are short enough to stick-clip the whole thing, and many can be accessed from above relatively easily if you get shutdown on lead. This is a great place to test your onsighting skills if you are a hard 5.11 climber. Lots of hidden holds and technical moves. It's obviously not world-class climbing by any means, but certainly worth a visit. 

  As of Dec 2016, all of the anchors have been replaced with modern hardware and in most cases steel lowering biners. 

Topo of Minor Wall

Overall lay of the land
